original_data.question: A 22-year-old woman with a history of asthma visits her physician for worsening shortness of breath. She states that she feels as though her “lungs are falling apart,” noting that her lung function has been steadily deteriorating. She further states that she has visited a number of other physicians who prescribed several different types of inhalers, but she feels that they have not helped her control her asthma exacerbations. She has experienced 4 episodes of pneumonia in the last 3 years and often suffers from “random” bouts of excessive coughing and wheezing. When asked if her coughing episodes produce sputum, she states, “Yes, the stuff is greenish with specks of red in it.” She also states that her coughing and wheezing episodes are associated with fever, malaise, and occasional expectoration of brown mucous plugs. The vital signs include: blood pressure 122/70 mm Hg, pulse 66/min, respiratory rate 26/min, and temperature 37.0°C (98.6°F). On physical exam, the patient appears frail-looking and in moderate respiratory distress. Auscultation reveals inspiratory crackles in the right lung base and coarse breath sounds in the bilateral upper lung lobes. Chest radiograph, as shown below, reveals atelectasis in the right lung base. There are also branched radiodensities that the radiologist notes as being “glove-finger shadows” (noted by the arrow in the image). Serum immunoglobulin E (IgE) levels are elevated. Which of the following is the most appropriate therapy in this patient?

model_response:
The patient’s presentation is consistent with right-sided bronchiectasis and bilateral upper lobe “finger clubbing” suggestive of allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA). ABPA is a hypersensitivity reaction to the fungus Aspergillus. ABPA is most common in patients with asthma and cystic fibrosis. ABPA is characterized by episodic bronchial obstruction with mucous plugs, which can lead to coughing fits, wheezing, and atelectasis. The presence of eosinophilia and elevated serum IgE levels support the diagnosis of ABPA. Glucocorticoids are the mainstay of therapy for ABPA. Isoniazid is used for prophylaxis against tuberculosis. Fluconazole is an antifungal medication used to treat Candida infections. Caspofungin is another antifungal medication used to treat Candida infections.

Image source- style="font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif">

###Answer: OPTION D IS CORRECT.</s><s>

Groups that serve as a standard for comparison in experimental studies. They are similar in relevant characteristics to the experimental group but do not receive the experimental intervention.

A form of bronchial disorder with three distinct components: airway hyper-responsiveness (RESPIRATORY HYPERSENSITIVITY), airway INFLAMMATION, and intermittent AIRWAY OBSTRUCTION. It is characterized by spasmodic contraction of airway smooth muscle, WHEEZING, and dyspnea (DYSPNEA, PAROXYSMAL).
A worsening of a problem, condition, or disease.
A noteworthy happening that is distinctive in a series of related events.
Infection of the lung often accompanied by inflammation.
A period of time that it takes for Earth to make a complete revolution around the sun, approximately 365 days; a specific one year period.
State of severe distress associated with events that threaten the intactness of the person, can be physical, mental, or emotional.
Governed by or depending on chance; lacking any definite plan or order or purpose.
Beyond normal limits; unrestrained.

A sudden, audible expulsion of air from the lungs through a partially closed glottis, preceded by inhalation. It is a protective response that serves to clear the trachea, bronchi, and/or lungs of irritants and secretions, or to prevent aspiration of foreign materials into the lungs.

A symptom and a finding during physical examination, characterized by a high-pitched, whistling sound during breathing. It results from the narrowing or obstruction of the respiratory airways. The most common causes of wheezing are asthma, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, tracheobronchitis, and pulmonary edema.

Material coughed up from the lungs and expectorated via the mouth. It contains MUCUS, cellular debris, and microorganisms. It may also contain blood or pus.

The most common causes of wheezing are asthma, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, tracheobronchitis, and pulmonary edema.

Material coughed up from the lungs and expectorated via the mouth. It contains MUCUS, cellular debris, and microorganisms. It may also contain blood or pus.

PRESSURE of the BLOOD on the ARTERIES and other BLOOD VESSELS.
A metric unit of length equal to one thousandth of a meter (10E-3 meter) or approximately 0.03937 inch.
The rhythmical expansion and contraction of an ARTERY produced by waves of pressure caused by the ejection of BLOOD from the left ventricle of the HEART as it contracts.
The rate of breathing (inhalation and exhalation) measured within in a unit time, usually expressed as breaths per minute.
The measure of the level of heat of a human or animal.

Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.

Privacy metadata indicating the level of protection required to safeguard personal and healthcare information, which if disclosed without authorization, would present a moderate risk of harm to an individual's reputation and sense of privacy.

Usage Note:The level of protection afforded moderately confidential information is dictated by privacy policies intended to engender trust in a service provider. May include publicly available information in jurisdictions that restrict uses of that information without the consent of the data subject.

Privacy policies mandating moderate levels of protection, which preempt less protective privacy policies. "Moderate" confidentiality policies differ from and would be preempted by the prevailing privacy policies mandating the normative level of protection for information used in the delivery and management of healthcare.

Confidentiality code total order hierarchy: Moderate (M) is less protective thanV, R, and N*, and subsumes all other protection levels (i.e., *Land *U*).Examples:Includes personal and health information that an individual authorizes to be collected, accessed, used or disclosed to a bank for a health credit card or savings account; to health oversight authorities; to a hospital patient directory; to worker compensation, disability, property and casualty or life insurers; and to personal health record systems, consumer-controlled devices, social media accounts and online Apps; or for marketing purposes
A pathological increase in the effort and frequency of breathing movements.
Act of listening for sounds within the body.
Crackles that are heard during the inspiratory phase. [PMID:26229557]
Noises, normal and abnormal, heard on auscultation over any part of the RESPIRATORY TRACT.
Affecting both sides of the body or a matched pair of organs.

The lobe of the right lung that lies above the oblique and horizontal fissures and includes the apical, posterior and anterior bronchopulmonary segments; in the left lung, the lobe lies above the oblique fissure and contains the apicoposterior, anterior, superior lingular and inferior lingular segments.

Absence of air in the entire or part of a lung, such as an incompletely inflated neonate lung or a collapsed adult lung. Pulmonary atelectasis can be caused by airway obstruction, lung compression, fibrotic contraction, or other factors.
A part of a forking structure; a division or offshoot from a main stem.
The transparency of a material to the passage of X-rays and other forms of radiation.
Physicians specializing in the use of x-ray and other forms of radiant energy to diagnose and treat disease.

Description:A characteristic representing a single file reference that contains two or more views of the same dosage form of the product; in most cases this should represent front and back views of the dosage form, but occasionally additional views might be needed in order to capture all of the important physical characteristics of the dosage form. Any imprint and/or symbol should be clearly identifiable, and the viewer should not normally need to rotate the image in order to read it. Images that are submitted with SPL should be included in the same directory as the SPL file.
A position on a scale measuring intensity, quality, or amount.
An elevated level or position or degree; greater than normal in degree or intensity or amount.

Used with diseases for therapeutic interventions except drug therapy, diet therapy, radiotherapy, and surgery, for which specific subheadings exist. The concept is also used for articles and books dealing with multiple therapies.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
